awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  VoxCare: Artificial Intelligence-based Monitoring for Substance Use Indicators in Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce the $740B a year burden of substance use. Healthcare costs, crime, and lost productivity are only a fraction of the problem that has claimed over 100,000 lives in 2021 alone. The proposed innovation is a novel AI-based technology integrated into a mobile app that allows the assessment of drug use or alcohol intoxication based on voice signals. Substance and alcohol use disorders are prevalent across every stratum of our society.  Not only are the users impacted, but the penumbra of individuals impacted includes every citizen in the US. Preventing early exposure to illicit drugs and alcohol lowers the likelihood of developing severe addiction later in life. By disrupting normal brain development, various substances increase the long-term negative effects on a child’s life. Given the skyrocketing rates of depression and anxiety among teenagers, the wide availability of highly potent synthetic substances, and the ease of access to drugs, parents feel ill-equipped to protect their children.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase 1 project will help advance knowledge in several important areas, such as artificial intelligence capabilities, leveraging digital media platforms for data collection, synthetic audio data generation, and using the mix of temporal and spectral domains for audio analysis. Each area is an active research field, but the combination of all these areas into a product for analyzing voice to detect intoxication caused by various substances has not been previously attempted by academia or industry. The company’s technology relies on the unique impact that each substance use has on neuromotor function, as manifested by the bio-mechanical process of voice production. By comparing the voice signal against the speakers’ baseline voice, the technology will flag abnormal deviations of acoustic features that are typically consistent with intoxication. The field of voice analysis integrates a range of features and signal characteristics to extract valuable insights from voice signals. The primary objectives are to develop and deploy this AI-based technology in ubiquitous devices such as mobile phones while ensuring its performance in real-life conditions and achieving soft real-time processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Impairment in the workplace presents a big problem that can lead to project delays, accidents, injuries and additional costs, including higher insurance premiums. Certain sectors including nuclear power generation, oil and gas production and petrochemicals have very low risk tolerance when it comes to human error since accidents can affect not only the employees and the organizations but our planet as a whole. Workplace injuries alone cost US companies over $136 Billion annually.

There are a few factors that are causing the employers to allocate more resources towards risk mitigation. One of them is the sharp increase in extreme jury awards exceeding $10 million. According to the Travelers Institute, extreme jury awards have gone up significantly. From 2015 to 2019, the average verdict in the National Law Journal’s Top 100 Verdicts more than tripled from $64 million to $214 million. These verdicts are creating challenges for the insurance industry and employers, making it difficult to underwrite potential legal risks, increasing premiums and threatening to put liability insurance out of reach for businesses. These trends are influencing corporations’ risk tolerance and are pushing companies towards adopting more innovative risk reduction solutions.

The status quo for impairment detection is that the enterprises rely heavily on subjective assessment by supervisors who are juggling a dozen other priorities throughout the workday. In addition to taking away time from the managers’ other tasks, heavy reliance on subjective impairment assessment creates opportunities for bias and potential interpersonal conflicts. One longitudinal study found that Black workers reported 15-20% higher drug testing rates in their workplaces, than their Hispanic and White counterparts. According to the National Safety Council (NSC), a public service organization that promotes health and safety in the United States and has 55,000 member organizations (NSC), less than half (46%) of surveyed organizations believed that employees would feel comfortable telling their supervisors or co-workers if they were too impaired to perform their job.

Tenvos has created a voice-based impairment solution that screens using only 6 seconds of speech. Extensive market research and Customer Discovery interviews during the Beat the Odds bootcamp led to a pivot in product design and market fit. Originally, we planned to develop an application for real-time screening for impairment in youth. We have since pivoted towards impairment screening for safety-sensitive industries such as petrochemical, mining, and transportation. In doing so, we have found rapid success in market-fit and have evolved into an end-to-end platform. Over the past eight months, we have focused on refining this platform through hands-on experience with commercial pilots in a safety-critical industry. Participant retention was 100%, confirming the high acceptability of the product in real world contexts. Post-pilot survey results included:  100% of participants found the app easy to use, 83% of participants wanted access to fatigue analysis results to address factors relating to their fatigue levels, 75% felt that the pilot improved staff morale and 67% reported being more aware of fatigue in relation to their work safety.

Substantial adjustments to the underlying technology and user experience have resulted in an accurate, easy to use system, with excellent end-user experience. Tenvos’ technology is the first of its kind solution to empower employers and employees alike with data and help them manage impairment risk before it leads to workplace incidents and near-misses.

Objective, voice-based impairment testing holds incredible promise in reducing workplace incidents by providing a non-invasive, lightweight and accurate alternative to the status quo and competing products when it comes to managing risk.

Fatigue and Substance Use Disorders are the two leading causes of preventable worker injury and unnecessary employer costs. Controlling these risks will have a profound effect on workplace safety. The societal costs of occupational incidents reach far beyond clean-up costs. The British Petroleum corporation estimated the cost of the Deepwater Horizon incident to be around $2 billion when in fact over $20 billion were spent in order to manage the consequences of the oil spill. The Chernobyl nuclear disaster is another example of an occupational accident that resulted from control room workers pushing 13 hour shifts. The cost of the catastrophe is still difficult to quantify. The Tenvos platform aims to reduce occupational incidents due to worker impairment, thus contributing to lower societal and environmental impacts from these events.

Occupational health and safety is not just about the employees or corporations, it’s about our planet. Development of solutions for mitigating the risks of worker impairment will ensure that the most critical sectors are operating safely, efficiently and sustainably.
